<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx';
	}
</script>

<meta name="post_tags" content="double extortion,INC ransomware,Leak site,Lynx ransomware"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Lynx Ransomware: A Rebranding of INC Ransomware","name":"Lynx Ransomware: A Rebranding of INC Ransomware","description":"Discover recent attacks using Lynx ransomware, a rebrand of INC, targeting multiple crucial sectors in the U.S. and UK with prevalent double-extortion tactics.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx\/","datePublished":"October 10, 2024","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nIn July 2024, researchers from Palo Alto Networks discovered a successor to INC ransomware named Lynx. Since its emergence, the group behind this ransomware has actively targeted organizations in various sectors such as retail, real estate, architecture, and financial and environmental services in the U.S. and UK.\r\n\r\nLynx ransomware shares a significant portion of its source code with INC ransomware. INC ransomware initially surfaced in August 2023 and had variants compatible with both Windows and Linux. While we haven't confirmed any Linux samples yet for Lynx ransomware, we have noted Windows samples. This ransomware operates using a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) model.\r\n\r\nThis article delves into the timeline of these more recent attacks and the evolving tactics employed by the threat actor behind this ransomware.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from Lynx ransomware through our Network Security solutions and Cortex line of products.\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nRansomware, Double Extortion\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nActivity Timeline\r\nFigure 1 below shows a timeline comparing the number of confirmed samples we have discovered for both INC and Lynx ransomware. This graph presents a comparison of the sample count for both INC and Lynx ransomware on a monthly basis from October 2023 through September 2024.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137050\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 1. INC versus Lynx ransomware sample timeline.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe source code for INC ransomware was available for sale on the criminal underground market as early as March 2024. Because of this, we expect many malware authors to acquire and repackage this code to develop new ransomware, similar to what the Lynx group did. As a result, we can expect a growing trend in which newer or different ransomware groups reuse this existing code.\r\nDelivery Mechanism\r\nThe group behind Lynx ransomware represents an increasingly prevalent and sophisticated double-extortion threat. The threat operators commonly disseminate their ransomware through a variety of cyberattack vectors.\r\n\r\nThese vectors include:\r\n\r\n \tPhishing emails that deceive users into revealing sensitive information\r\n \tMalicious downloads that surreptitiously install the ransomware onto victims' systems\r\n \tHacking forums where cybercriminals share information and resources\r\n\r\nThe double extortion aspect of Lynx ransomware means that it exfiltrates a victim's data before encrypting it. This not only encrypts the victim's data, rendering it inaccessible, but also allows the ransomware group to leak or sell this information if the victim does not make a ransom payment.\r\n\r\nLike other ransomware groups, this multifaceted approach to cyberextortion has made Lynx ransomware a formidable threat to individuals and organizations alike. This necessitates organizations to develop robust cybersecurity measures to counteract its impact.\r\nData Leak Site\r\nThe group asserts that it has breached data from numerous companies and has publicly displayed the pilfered information on its website at http[:]\/\/lynxblog[.]net as demonstrated in Figures 2 and 3.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137052\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 2. Leaked data published on the Lynx ransomware website.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137054\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 3. Leaked data with total income, date and size of data.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe group has a strict policy and recently released a statement on their activities as shown in Figure 4. This group states it is financially motivated, but it claims it does not target government institutes, hospitals or non-profit organizations.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137056\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 4. Leaked data published on the Lynx ransomware website.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThis group has also created a reporting page for its operations as shown in Figure 5.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137058\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"700\"] Figure 5. Reporting form on the Lynx ransomware website.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nBelow, Figure 6 highlights the logo used for Lynx ransomware as seen on its website.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137060\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"500\"] Figure 6. Lynx ransomware logo used on its website.[\/caption]\r\nTechnical Analysis of Lynx Ransomware\r\nThe Lynx ransomware samples we analyzed used AES-128 in CTR mode and Curve25519 Donna encryption algorithms. All files are encrypted and have the .lynx extension appended to them. This malware version is designed for the Windows platform and is written in the C++ programming language.\r\n\r\nAttackers can tailor their execution of Lynx ransomware by using arguments supplied during runtime as illustrated in Figure 7.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137062\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 7. Command-line options present in the malware.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe ransomware\u2019s features include the following:\r\n\r\n \tDesignating specific directories\/files for encryption\r\n \tTerminating services\/processes\r\n \tEncrypting network drives\r\n \tMounting concealed disks\r\n \tEnabling or disabling background image alterations\r\n \tPrinting all console logs\r\n\r\nFigure 8 shows code snippets for various arguments available for Lynx ransomware. It can even load hidden drives and encrypt network share drives.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137064\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 8. Encryption mode in the malware.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIf no arguments are given, the ransomware defaults to encrypting all files and drives on the system. Additionally, it deletes shadow copies and backup partition drives as shown in Figure 9.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137066\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"684\"] Figure 9. Running a Lynx ransomware sample with default arguments in a command terminal.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAs noted from the debugger results in Figure 10, the ransomware scans all the drives, attempts to mount them, then encrypts the data they contain.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137068\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"644\"] Figure 10. Lynx ransomware sample checking for drive letters.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nBefore starting the encryption process, the sample would kill the processes on the system listed in Figure 11 below.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137070\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"641\"] Figure 11. Lynx checking for various processes in the system.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFigure 12 shows code snippets illustrating this process.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137072\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 12. Code snippets checking process and termination.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nLike many other ransomware strains, Lynx ransomware uses the Restart Manager API RstrtMgr to enhance its encryption capabilities and maximize its impact on the victim's system. By incorporating RstrtMgr into its attack process, Lynx ransomware can target files that are currently in use or locked by other applications.\r\n\r\nRstrtMgr helps the ransomware identify which applications are using the desired files. Ransomware such as Conti, Cactus and BiBi Wiper have also been observed employing this technique.\r\n\r\nAfter the ransomware encrypts all files, it attempts to print a report via Microsoft OneNote as shown in the debugger output in Figure 13 and the command-line output in Figure 14.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137074\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"600\"] Figure 13. Debugger output showing a Lynx ransomware sample sending notes to OneNote.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137076\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 14. After running Lynx ransomware from the command line, the output revealed it sent notes to OneNote on completion of encryption.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFigure 15 below shows that the ransomware appends a .lynx extension to all encrypted file names.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137078\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 15. Desktop from a Lynx ransomware infection with the .lynx file extension appended to encrypted files.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe presence of a program database (PDB) path with Lynx in the name confirms the ransomware as a Lynx variant, as shown in the output of a packed executable (PE) analyzer tool in Figure 16.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137080\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"300\"] Figure 16. Lynx sample .pdb path.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nLynx additionally drops a README.txt file as a ransom note. Figure 17 displays both the Base64-encoded content found in the sample data section of a Lynx ransomware sample and the decoded ransom note.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137082\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 17. Ransom note Base64-encoded text from the Lynx ransomware sample and the decoded ransom note.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFigure 18 below shows a different ransom note from another Lynx ransomware sample.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137084\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 18. Ransom note from another Lynx ransomware sample.[\/caption]\r\nComparison With INC Ransomware\r\nWe used the open-source tool BinDiff to compare the code between a sample of Lynx ransomware and a sample of INC ransomware. Figure 19 shows the BinDiff results from the INC sample in the Primary Call Graph (bottom right) and the Lynx sample in the Secondary Call Graph (bottom left). By analyzing and cross-referencing the call graphs of both ransomware samples, we can observe the extent to which their code structures and functionalities overlap and diverge.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_137086\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 19. Code similarity between INC and Lynx ransomware as shown by BinDiff.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nUpon close examination, we find that the overall matched functions between both ransomware samples stand at 48%. This indicates that nearly half of the functions present in the INC ransomware sample are also used in the Lynx sample.\r\n\r\nThe percentage of matched functions rises to an impressive 70.8% when we consider functions that are common to both ransomware families. This significant overlap in shared functions strongly suggests that the developers of Lynx ransomware have borrowed and repurposed a considerable portion of the INC codebase to create their own malicious software.\r\n\r\nReusing code between different ransomware families is common among cybercriminals. By leveraging preexisting code and building upon the foundations laid by other successful ransomware, threat actors can save time and resources in the development of their own attacks. This can ultimately lead to more successful and widespread campaigns.\r\nConclusion\r\nLynx ransomware use is active and evolving, yet attackers often employ similar code patterns in newer versions. Palo Alto Networks monitors such campaigns and uses various static and dynamic methods for detecting and blocking them.\r\n\r\nRansomware is a familiar presence in the threat landscape, and there are numerous approaches to protecting customers from these evolving attacks. These methods include dynamic and behavioral detections, as well as more reactive signature or pattern-based solutions.\r\nPalo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from Lynx ransomware through the following products:\r\n\r\n \tThe Cortex XDR Anti-Ransomware module protects against the threats described in both versions of the malware: Windows and Linux.\u00a0\r\n \t\u00a0Advanced WildFire: The Advanced WildFire machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the IoCs shared in this research.\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tEMEA: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAPAC: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nSHA256 hashes of Windows EXE samples for Lynx ransomware:\r\n\r\n \t571f5de9dd0d509ed7e5242b9b7473c2b2cbb36ba64d38b32122a0a337d6cf8b\r\n \t82eb1910488657c78bef6879908526a2a2c6c31ab2f0517fcc5f3f6aa588b513\r\n \teaa0e773eb593b0046452f420b6db8a47178c09e6db0fa68f6a2d42c3f48e3bc\r\n\r\nSHA256 hashes of Windows EXE samples for INC ransomware:\r\n\r\n \t11cfd8e84704194ff9c56780858e9bbb9e82ff1b958149d74c43969d06ea10bd\r\n \t1754c9973bac8260412e5ec34bf5156f5bb157aa797f95ff4fc905439b74357a\r\n \t1a7c754ae1933338c740c807ec3dcf5e18e438356990761fdc2e75a2685ebf4a\r\n \t29a25e971dbb87d3adcee75693782d978a3ca9f64df0a59b015ca519a4026c49\r\n \t3156ee399296d55e56788b487701eb07fd5c49db04f80f5ab3dc5c4e3c071be0\r\n \t36e3c83e50a19ad1048dab7814f3922631990578aab0790401bc67dbcc90a72e\r\n \t508a644d552f237615d1504aa1628566fe0e752a5bc0c882fa72b3155c322cef\r\n \t64b249eb3ab5993e7bcf5c0130e5f31cbd79dabdcad97268042780726e68533f\r\n \t7f104a3dfda3a7fbdd9b910d00b0169328c5d2facc10dc17b4378612ffa82d51\r\n \t869d6ae8c0568e40086fd817766a503bfe130c805748e7880704985890aca947\r\n \t9ac550187c7c27a52c80e1c61def1d3d5e6dbae0e4eaeacf1a493908ffd3ec7d\r\n \tca9d2440850b730ba03b3a4f410760961d15eb87e55ec502908d2546cd6f598c\r\n \td147b202e98ce73802d7501366a036ea8993c4c06cdfc6921899efdd22d159c6\r\n \te17c601551dfded76ab99a233957c5c4acf0229b46cd7fc2175ead7fe1e3d261\r\n \tee1d8ac9fef147f0751000c38ca5d72feceeaae803049a2cd49dcce15223b720\r\n \tf96ecd567d9a05a6adb33f07880eebf1d6a8709512302e363377065ca8f98f56\r\n \tfcefe50ed02c8d315272a94f860451bfd3d86fa6ffac215e69dfa26a7a5deced\r\n \tfef674fce37d5de43a4d36e86b2c0851d738f110a0d48bae4b2dab4c6a2c373e\r\n\r\nSHA256 hashes of Linux ELF samples for INC ransomware:\r\n\r\n \t63e0d4e861048f581c9e5c64b28a053eb0023d58eebf2b943868d5f68a67a8b7\r\n \ta0ceb258924ef004fa4efeef4bc0a86012afdb858e855ed14f1bbd31ca2e42f5\r\n \tc41ab33986921c812c51e7a86bd3fd0691f5bba925fae612f1b717afaa2fe0ef\r\n\r\nContact email address from Lynx ransomware note:\r\n\r\n \tmartina.lestariid1898@proton[.]me\r\n\r\nPublicly accessible leak site blog for Lynx ransomware:\r\n\r\n \tlynxblog[.]net\r\n\r\nTor URLs for Lynx ransomware:\r\n\r\n \thttp[:]\/\/lynxbllrfr5262yvbgtqoyq76s7mpztcqkv6tjjxgpilpma7nyoeohyd[.]onion\r\n \thttp[:]\/\/lynxbllrfr5262yvbgtqoyq76s7mpztcqkv6tjjxgpilpma7nyoeohyd[.]onion\/disclosures\r\n \thttp[:]\/\/lynxblogco7r37jt7p5wrmfxzqze7ghxw6rihzkqc455qluacwotciyd[.]onion\r\n <script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

</head>

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Finc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Facebook" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:share:facebook"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-fb-share.svg" alt="Facebook Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Finc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx%2F&#038;title=Lynx%20Ransomware:%20A%20Rebranding%20of%20INC%20Ransomware" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in LinkedIn" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:share:linkedin"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-linkedin-share.svg" alt="LinkedIn Icon"></a>

				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="//www.reddit.com/submit?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Finc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Reddit" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:share:reddit"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-reddit-share.svg" alt="Reddit Icon"></a>

	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-137046-_7cla2kykl4ij"></a><strong>Executive Summary</strong></h2>
<p>In July 2024, researchers from Palo Alto Networks discovered a successor to INC ransomware named Lynx. Since its emergence, the group behind this ransomware has actively targeted organizations in various sectors such as retail, real estate, architecture, and financial and environmental services in the U.S. and UK.</p>
<p>Lynx ransomware shares a significant portion of its source code with INC ransomware. INC ransomware initially surfaced in August 2023 and had variants compatible with both Windows and Linux. While we haven't confirmed any Linux samples yet for Lynx ransomware, we have noted Windows samples. This ransomware operates using a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) model.</p>
<p>This article delves into the timeline of these more recent attacks and the evolving tactics employed by the threat actor behind this ransomware.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from Lynx ransomware through our <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Network Security</a> solutions and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex</a> line of products.</p>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/ransomware/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Ransomware</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/double-extortion/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Double Extortion</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-137046-_88ih18br06x3"></a><strong>Activity Timeline</strong></h2>
<p>Figure 1 below shows a timeline comparing the number of confirmed samples we have discovered for both INC and Lynx ransomware. This graph presents a comparison of the sample count for both INC and Lynx ransomware on a monthly basis from October 2023 through September 2024.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137050" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137050" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137050" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/chart.png" alt="Stacked bar chart showing counts of Lynx ransomware and INC ransomware incidents from September 2023 to September 2024. INC ransomware incidents peak in June 2024, while Lync ransomware shows notable occurrence in August and September 2024. INC ransomware is absent by September. " width="900" height="359" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/chart.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/chart-786x313.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/chart-1757x700.png 1757w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/chart-768x306.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/chart-1536x612.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137050" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. INC versus Lynx ransomware sample timeline.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The source code for INC ransomware <a href="https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/inc-ransomware-source-code-selling-on-hacking-forums-for-300-000/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">was available for sale on the criminal underground market as early as March 2024</a>. Because of this, we expect many malware authors to acquire and repackage this code to develop new ransomware, similar to what the Lynx group did. As a result, we can expect a growing trend in which newer or different ransomware groups reuse this existing code.</p>
<h2><a id="post-137046-_ujw86m4z1x8g"></a><strong>Delivery Mechanism</strong></h2>
<p>The group behind Lynx ransomware represents an increasingly prevalent and sophisticated double-extortion threat. The threat operators commonly disseminate their ransomware through a variety of cyberattack vectors.</p>
<p>These vectors include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Phishing emails that deceive users into revealing sensitive information</li>
<li>Malicious downloads that surreptitiously install the ransomware onto victims' systems</li>
<li>Hacking forums where cybercriminals share information and resources</li>
</ul>
<p>The double extortion aspect of Lynx ransomware means that it exfiltrates a victim's data before encrypting it. This not only encrypts the victim's data, rendering it inaccessible, but also allows the ransomware group to leak or sell this information if the victim does not make a ransom payment.</p>
<p>Like other ransomware groups, this multifaceted approach to cyberextortion has made Lynx ransomware a formidable threat to individuals and organizations alike. This necessitates organizations to develop robust cybersecurity measures to counteract its impact.</p>
<h2><a id="post-137046-_qngj3oyrcxk1"></a><strong>Data Leak Site</strong></h2>
<p>The group asserts that it has breached data from numerous companies and has publicly displayed the pilfered information on its website at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">http[:]//lynxblog[.]net</span> as demonstrated in Figures 2 and 3.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137052" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137052" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137052" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-968766-137046-2.jpeg" alt="Screenshot of the Lynx Leaks web interface displaying various reports. Each report is presented with titles, publication dates, descriptions, viewer counts, and a 'Go to the publication' button. The background is dark with the text and buttons highlighted in blue tones." width="900" height="426" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-968766-137046-2.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-968766-137046-2-786x372.jpeg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-968766-137046-2-1478x700.jpeg 1478w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-968766-137046-2-768x364.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-968766-137046-2-1536x728.jpeg 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137052" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Leaked data published on the Lynx ransomware website.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_137054" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137054" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137054" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-971789-137046-3.jpeg" alt="A blurred screenshot of the Lynx leak site interface displaying several navigation options like News and Reports. The main panel shows obscured text fields and image thumbnails, indicating a focus on media or publications. The interface theme is dark with hints of blue highlights." width="900" height="427" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-971789-137046-3.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-971789-137046-3-786x373.jpeg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-971789-137046-3-1476x700.jpeg 1476w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-971789-137046-3-768x364.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-971789-137046-3-1536x728.jpeg 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137054" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Leaked data with total income, date and size of data.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The group has a strict policy and recently released a statement on their activities as shown in Figure 4. This group states it is financially motivated, but it claims it does not target government institutes, hospitals or non-profit organizations.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137056" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137056" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137056" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-975051-137046-4.png" alt="Press release from Lynx ransomeware on July 24, 2024, discussing their approach to avoid harm to organizations by incentivizing ethical considerations and fostering dialogue for better economic and social outcomes." width="900" height="621" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-975051-137046-4.png 1726w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-975051-137046-4-638x440.png 638w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-975051-137046-4-1015x700.png 1015w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-975051-137046-4-768x530.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-975051-137046-4-1536x1059.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137056" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Leaked data published on the Lynx ransomware website.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This group has also created a reporting page for its operations as shown in Figure 5.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137058" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137058" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137058" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-979022-137046-5.png" alt="A screenshot of a digital 'Report' form with fields to enter a name, email, and a description. Below these, there is a captcha asking to solve a mathematical addition problem. A 'Send' button is provided at the bottom." width="700" height="732" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-979022-137046-5.png 1412w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-979022-137046-5-421x440.png 421w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-979022-137046-5-670x700.png 670w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-979022-137046-5-768x803.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137058" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Reporting form on the Lynx ransomware website.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Below, Figure 6 highlights the logo used for Lynx ransomware as seen on its website.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137060" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137060" style="width: 500px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137060" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-982058-137046-6.png" alt="Logo of Lynx featuring a stylized shield with a lynx head silhouette in white on a black background." width="500" height="158" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137060" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Lynx ransomware logo used on its website.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-137046-_k06bvehjehbx"></a><strong>Technical Analysis of Lynx Ransomware</strong></h2>
<p>The Lynx ransomware samples we analyzed used AES-128 in <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CTR mode</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Curve25519</span> Donna encryption algorithms. All files are encrypted and have the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lynx</span> extension appended to them. This malware version is designed for the Windows platform and is written in the C++ programming language.</p>
<p>Attackers can tailor their execution of Lynx ransomware by using arguments supplied during runtime as illustrated in Figure 7.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137062" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137062" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137062" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-984682-137046-7.png" alt="Command prompt screen displaying a list of arguments. The arguments include options for file encryption, verbose output, encryption of network shares, and others. Some identifying information is redacted." width="900" height="382" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-984682-137046-7.png 1269w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-984682-137046-7-786x334.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-984682-137046-7-768x326.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137062" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Command-line options present in the malware.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The ransomware’s features include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Designating specific directories/files for encryption</li>
<li>Terminating services/processes</li>
<li>Encrypting network drives</li>
<li>Mounting concealed disks</li>
<li>Enabling or disabling background image alterations</li>
<li>Printing all console logs</li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 8 shows code snippets for various arguments available for Lynx ransomware. It can even load hidden drives and encrypt network share drives.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137064" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137064" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137064" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-988253-137046-8.png" alt="Screenshot of computer code in an IDE, featuring multiple lines of code with functions involving encryption, verbosity, and process management." width="900" height="357" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-988253-137046-8.png 985w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-988253-137046-8-786x312.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-988253-137046-8-768x305.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137064" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Encryption mode in the malware.</figcaption></figure>
<p>If no arguments are given, the ransomware defaults to encrypting all files and drives on the system. Additionally, it deletes shadow copies and backup partition drives as shown in Figure 9.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137066" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137066" style="width: 684px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137066" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-991618-137046-9.png" alt="A screenshot of a computer screen displaying a command prompt window with various system processes being executed, including stopping processes, initializing threads, and encrypting files. The window shows several file paths and status messages related to system security. Some identifying information in the first line is redacted. " width="684" height="387" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137066" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Running a Lynx ransomware sample with default arguments in a command terminal.</figcaption></figure>
<p>As noted from the debugger results in Figure 10, the ransomware scans all the drives, attempts to mount them, then encrypts the data they contain.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137068" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137068" style="width: 644px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137068" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-994270-137046-10.png" alt="A screenshot of a computer screen displaying assembly language code with various memory addresses and operations." width="644" height="503" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-994270-137046-10.png 644w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-994270-137046-10-563x440.png 563w" sizes="(max-width: 644px) 100vw, 644px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137068" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Lynx ransomware sample checking for drive letters.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Before starting the encryption process, the sample would kill the processes on the system listed in Figure 11 below.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137070" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137070" style="width: 641px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137070" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-997656-137046-11.png" alt="A screenshot showing a section of computer code with various data offsets listed, such as Backup, Exchange, Java, and Notepad. One line is highlighted in purple with the word &quot;Veeam&quot; on the right side." width="641" height="101" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137070" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Lynx checking for various processes in the system.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 12 shows code snippets illustrating this process.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137072" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137072" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137072" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-779-137046-12.png" alt="A screenshot of computer code in an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) debugger environment with highlighted syntax in various colors, predominantly green and purple, indicating different elements like text, data, and operations." width="900" height="477" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-779-137046-12.png 1116w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-779-137046-12-786x417.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-779-137046-12-768x407.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137072" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Code snippets checking process and termination.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Like many other ransomware strains, Lynx ransomware uses the <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/rstmgr/restart-manager-portal" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Restart Manager</a> API <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RstrtMgr</span> to enhance its encryption capabilities and maximize its impact on the victim's system. By incorporating <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RstrtMgr</span> into its attack process, Lynx ransomware can target files that are currently in use or locked by other applications.</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RstrtMgr</span> helps the ransomware identify which applications are using the desired files. Ransomware such as Conti, Cactus and BiBi Wiper have also been observed employing this technique.</p>
<p>After the ransomware encrypts all files, it attempts to print a report via <a href="https://www.onenote.com/?public=1&amp;wdorigin=ondcauth2&amp;wdorigin=ondc" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Microsoft OneNote</a> as shown in the debugger output in Figure 13 and the command-line output in Figure 14.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137074" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137074" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137074" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-4051-137046-13.png" alt="A screenshot of a computer screen displaying code in an editor. The left side shows lines of hexadecimal values and assembly language, while the right side includes a text annotation. Red arrows point to two specific lines at the top and in the middle of the screenshot. " width="600" height="288" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-4051-137046-13.png 1424w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-4051-137046-13-786x378.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-4051-137046-13-768x369.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137074" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. Debugger output showing a Lynx ransomware sample sending notes to OneNote.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_137076" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137076" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137076" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-8872-137046-14.png" alt="Computer screen displaying multiple lines of text that indicate the process of sending notes to various versions of OneNote, including OneNote 2013, OneNote 2010, and OneNote for Windows 10. The text also includes messages about the successful closure of the same. These are highlighted inside a red box. Some identifying information is redacted. " width="900" height="297" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-8872-137046-14.png 2010w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-8872-137046-14-786x260.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-8872-137046-14-1920x634.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-8872-137046-14-768x254.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-8872-137046-14-1536x507.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137076" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. After running Lynx ransomware from the command line, the output revealed it sent notes to OneNote on completion of encryption.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 15 below shows that the ransomware appends a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lynx</span> extension to all encrypted file names.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137078" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137078" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137078" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-13574-137046-15.jpeg" alt="A computer desktop screen displaying an open folder named &quot;Documents&quot; with various files and folders listed, including &quot;Custom Office Templates&quot; and several Excel files. Icons for applications like Firefox, Google Chrome, and Microsoft Edge are visible on the taskbar. The desktop background has text saying that the computer's data is stolen and encrypted and there is contact information for Lynx. " width="900" height="506" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-13574-137046-15.jpeg 1492w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-13574-137046-15-782x440.jpeg 782w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-13574-137046-15-1245x700.jpeg 1245w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-13574-137046-15-768x432.jpeg 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137078" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 15. Desktop from a Lynx ransomware infection with the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lynx</span> file extension appended to encrypted files.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The presence of a program database (PDB) path with Lynx in the name confirms the ransomware as a Lynx variant, as shown in the output of a packed executable (PE) analyzer tool in Figure 16.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137080" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137080" style="width: 300px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137080" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-16711-137046-16.png" alt="Screenshot displaying file paths related to &quot;Lynx Release&quot; on a computer, with text highlighted in light blue on a dark blue background." width="300" height="57" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137080" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 16. Lynx sample <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.pdb</span> path.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Lynx additionally drops a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">README.txt</span> file as a ransom note. Figure 17 displays both the Base64-encoded content found in the sample data section of <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/eaa0e773eb593b0046452f420b6db8a47178c09e6db0fa68f6a2d42c3f48e3bc" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a Lynx ransomware sample</a> and the decoded ransom note.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137082" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137082" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137082" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-19264-137046-17.jpeg" alt="Screenshot of a Lynx ransomware sample code in a text editor, with highlighted areas showing Base64 text and its translation to ASCII text used for a ransom note." width="900" height="635" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-19264-137046-17.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-19264-137046-17-623x440.jpeg 623w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-19264-137046-17-991x700.jpeg 991w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-19264-137046-17-768x542.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-19264-137046-17-1536x1085.jpeg 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137082" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 17. Ransom note Base64-encoded text from the Lynx ransomware sample and the decoded ransom note.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 18 below shows a different ransom note from <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/571f5de9dd0d509ed7e5242b9b7473c2b2cbb36ba64d38b32122a0a337d6cf8b" target="_blank" rel="noopener">another Lynx ransomware sample</a>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137084" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137084" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137084" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-23244-137046-18.jpeg" alt="A screenshot of a text file named &quot;README.txt&quot; open in Notepad, displaying a list of Tor network mirror links for downloading a software. The file interface includes tabs for File, Edit, Format, View, and Help." width="900" height="628" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-23244-137046-18.jpeg 1820w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-23244-137046-18-631x440.jpeg 631w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-23244-137046-18-1003x700.jpeg 1003w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-23244-137046-18-768x536.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-23244-137046-18-1536x1072.jpeg 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137084" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 18. Ransom note from another Lynx ransomware sample.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-137046-_ixkcuyl7611u"></a><strong>Comparison With INC Ransomware</strong></h2>
<p>We used the open-source tool <a href="https://github.com/google/bindiff" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BinDiff</a> to compare the code between a sample of Lynx ransomware and a sample of INC ransomware. Figure 19 shows the BinDiff results from the INC sample in the Primary Call Graph (bottom right) and the Lynx sample in the Secondary Call Graph (bottom left). By analyzing and cross-referencing the call graphs of both ransomware samples, we can observe the extent to which their code structures and functionalities overlap and diverge.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137086" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137086" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-137086" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-27051-137046-19.png" alt="This image contains a series of graphs and charts displaying comparative data analysis between two code sets. It features pie charts illustrating categories such as Functions, Calls, Basic Blocks, and Jumps, a histogram showing Similarity percentage, and tables detailing specific metrics like function counts, calls, instructions, and more. The color coding and visual elements like percentages help to compare and contrast the data between the two sets effectively." width="900" height="436" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-27051-137046-19.png 1366w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-27051-137046-19-786x381.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/word-image-27051-137046-19-768x372.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137086" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 19. Code similarity between INC and Lynx ransomware as shown by <a href="https://www.zynamics.com/bindiff.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BinDiff</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Upon close examination, we find that the overall matched functions between both ransomware samples stand at 48%. This indicates that nearly half of the functions present in the INC ransomware sample are also used in the Lynx sample.</p>
<p>The percentage of matched functions rises to an impressive 70.8% when we consider functions that are common to both ransomware families. This significant overlap in shared functions strongly suggests that the developers of Lynx ransomware have borrowed and repurposed a considerable portion of the INC codebase to create their own malicious software.</p>
<p>Reusing code between different ransomware families is common among cybercriminals. By leveraging preexisting code and building upon the foundations laid by other successful ransomware, threat actors can save time and resources in the development of their own attacks. This can ultimately lead to more successful and widespread campaigns.</p>
<h2><a id="post-137046-_wg37n81gmd5r"></a><strong>Conclusion</strong></h2>
<p>Lynx ransomware use is active and evolving, yet attackers often employ similar code patterns in newer versions. Palo Alto Networks monitors such campaigns and uses various static and dynamic methods for detecting and blocking them.</p>
<p>Ransomware is a familiar presence in the threat landscape, and there are numerous approaches to protecting customers from these evolving attacks. These methods include dynamic and behavioral detections, as well as more reactive <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cyberpedia/what-is-a-payload-based-signature" target="_blank" rel="noopener">signature or pattern</a>-based solutions.</p>
<h3><a id="post-137046-_dml2n655qjx7"></a><strong>Palo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation</strong></h3>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from Lynx ransomware through the following products:</p>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Cortex XDR</span></a> <span style="font-weight: 400;">Anti-Ransomware module protects against the threats described in both versions of the malware: Windows and Linux. </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> </span><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Advanced WildFire</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">: The Advanced WildFire machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the IoCs shared in this research.                                            </span></li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-137046-_vl741f7mzldf"></a><strong>Indicators of Compromise</strong></h2>

<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">571f5de9dd0d509ed7e5242b9b7473c2b2cbb36ba64d38b32122a0a337d6cf8b</span></li>

</ul>

<h2><a id="post-137046-_d85bp8uka6nj"></a><strong>Additional References</strong></h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/inc-ransomware-source-code-selling-on-hacking-forums-for-300-000/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">INC ransomware source code selling on hacking forums for $300,000</a> – Bleeping Computer</li>
<li><a href="https://nikhilh-20.github.io/blog/inc_ransomware/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">INC Linux Ransomware - Sandboxing with ELFEN and Analysis</a> – M&amp;M: Malware and Musings by Nikhil "Kaido" Hegde</li>
</ul>

              <div class="be__post-nav">
    <a class="prev" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:article-nav:Threat Research Center"> 
        <span>Threat Research Center</span>
    </a>
            <a class="next" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/north-korean-threat-actors-lure-tech-job-seekers-as-fake-recruiters/" role="link" title="Contagious Interview: DPRK Threat Actors Lure Tech Industry Job Seekers to Install New Variants of BeaverTail and InvisibleFerret Malware" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:article-nav:Contagious Interview: DPRK Threat Actors Lure Tech Industry Job Seekers to Install New Variants of BeaverTail and InvisibleFerret Malware"> 
            <span>Next: Contagious Interview: DPRK Threat Actors Lure Tech Industry Job Seekers to Install New Variants of BeaverTail and InvisibleFerret Malware</span>
        </a>
    </div>
 
            </div>

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:related-resources:Ransomware Retrospective 2024: Unit 42 Leak Site Analysis:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit-42-ransomware-leak-site-data-analysis-all-2023/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:related-resources:Ransomware Retrospective 2024: Unit 42 Leak Site Analysis">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Ransomware Retrospective 2024: Unit 42 Leak Site Analysis</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/ambitious-scorpius/" title="Ambitious Scorpius" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:related-resources:Ransomware Retrospective 2024: Unit 42 Leak Site Analysis:Ambitious Scorpius">Ambitious Scorpius</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/ignoble-scorpius/" title="Ignoble Scorpius" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:related-resources:Ransomware Retrospective 2024: Unit 42 Leak Site Analysis:Ignoble Scorpius">Ignoble Scorpius</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/leak-site/" title="Leak site" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:related-resources:Ransomware Retrospective 2024: Unit 42 Leak Site Analysis:Leak site">Leak site</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">

                </div>
              </div>
            </div>

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="An illustration of a digital security concept featuring a transparent padlock superimposed over multiple hard drives illuminated by blue and red lights. The padlock displays coding and binary numbers, symbolizing data encryption and cybersecurity measures. The image is set against a dark background to enhance the glowing technological elements." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Ransomware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure>

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:related-resources:Threat Assessment: BianLian:High Profile Threats"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/top-threats.svg" alt=" category icon">High Profile Threats</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:related-resources:Threat Assessment: BianLian">

                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A digital illustration of a glowing red padlock symbol superimposed over a detailed circuit board background, emphasizing themes of cybersecurity and data protection. The image features vibrant red and blue lights to highlight the technological context." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure>

              <div class="card-content">

                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:related-resources:Medusa Ransomware Turning Your Files into Stone:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/medusa-ransomware-escalation-new-leak-site/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="inc-ransomware-rebrand-to-lynx:related-resources:Medusa Ransomware Turning Your Files into Stone">
